title: Pro Log: Nairo Quintana returns to Movistar, Tour de France routes revealed, Demi Vollering and Jonas Vingegaard win VÃ©lo dâ€™Or

Pro Log: Nairo Quintana returns to Movistar, Tour de France routes revealed, Demi Vollering and Jonas Vingegaard win VÃ©lo dâ€™Or

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. As the road cycling season winds down, the transfers and contract extensions ramp up.

Ineos Grenadiers has been busy, with 18-year-old American cyclist AJ August turning professional with the squad on a three-year deal. Ben Swift has signed a new two-year contract, and Laurens De Plus has extended for three years. Carlos RodrÃ­guez has also re-signed until the end of 2027.

Results powered by FirstCycling.com

Elsewhere, Jasper Philipsen (Alpecin-Deceuninck) beat Mark Cavendish (racing under â€˜Legendsâ€™ and not his Astana-Qazaqstan team) in a sprint finish at the Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium on 29th October.

Menâ€™s Tour de France 2024 route announced: What will riders face on the road from Florence to Nice?

1. Nairo Quintana signs one-year contract with Movistar

Confirmamos que @NairoQuinCo formarÃ¡ parte de la plantilla de #MovistarTeam2024.

https://t.co/evwPQCjsQg pic.twitter.com/9hjHnWzFaG

â€” Movistar Team (@Movistar_Team) October 28, 2023

Nairo Quintana has signed a one-year deal to return to Movistar. Quintana last rode professionally for ArkÃ©a-Samsic, but they parted ways after his Tour de France disqualification in 2022.

The 33-year-old was disqualified from the 2022 Tour de France â€“ in which he finished 6th on GC â€“ following a positive test for Tramadol. He was the first cyclist to be sanctioned for doing so.

Tramadol is an opioid painkiller whose side effects can include dizziness. A 2017 survey conducted by the UCI revealed that 68% of urine samples containing Tramadol â€“ taken from across 35 Olympic sports â€“ were from cyclists. While not a banned substance on the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) list at the time, Tramadol was still prohibited by the UCI. As the World Anti-Doping Agency has recently approved Tramadol to be on its list of prohibited substances from 2024, riders can now face a four-year suspension if they test positive.

Movistar confirmed the signing of Quintana with a press release that reads: â€˜Quintana returnsâ€¦ after his first spell from 2012 to 2019, years in which he turned into a beacon and representative for Latin America, well beyond cycling and sports in general.â€™

2. Tour de France routes announced

The routes for the 2024 Tour de France and Tour de France Femmes races were unveiled in Paris. The menâ€™s peloton will depart from Florence, Italy, and cover 14 gravel sectors and 52,230m of elevation gain on the way to Nice.Â Â 

Thatâ€™s right â€“ a reminder that the menâ€™s Tour de France will not finish on the Champs-Ã‰lysÃ©es next year due to the Olympic Games also being held in Paris. Instead, the three weeks will culminate with a 34km individual time-trial from Monaco to Nice.Â 

For the first time in three years, the 2024 Tour de France Femmes will host a foreign Grand DÃ©part, with the race kicking off in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The peloton will then head from the Netherlands into Belgium for a mini-mixture of Amstel Gold and LiÃ¨ge-Bastogne-LiÃ¨ge, before hitting French soil on Stage 4.Â 

A mountainous final weekend awaits. Stage 7 marks the longest day in the saddle at 167km as Stage 8 finishes with a dramatic ascent of Alpe dâ€™Huez.Â Â 

3. Vollering and Vingegaard win VÃ©lo dâ€™Or awardÂ 

Demi Vollering and Jonas Vingegaard win the VÃ©lo d'Or awards for 2023. Based on scores from an international panel of journalists, Vollering got 171 points, ahead of Kopecky (139) and Van Vleuten (99). Vingegaard got 142 points, Van der Poel (133), PogaÄar (126) pic.twitter.com/NUcWA0Jwzg

â€” the Inner Ring (@inrng) October 24, 2023

Demi Vollering (SD Worx) and Jonas Vingegaard (Jumbo-Visma) won the VÃ©lo dâ€™Or awards for 2023. Created in 1992 by VÃ©lo magazine, the award honours the seasonâ€™s best cyclists as determined by a jury. The womenâ€™s VÃ©lo dâ€™Or has only been in existence since 2022.Â 

Vollering topped the Womenâ€™s WorldTour standings in 2023, successfully completing the Ardennes Classics triple (Amstel Gold Race, FlÃ¨che Wallonne and LiÃ¨ge-Bastogne-LiÃ¨ge) as well as a thrilling overall victory at the Tour de France Femmes. Vingegaard also won the Tour de France ahead of Tadej PogaÄar, with general classification victories in Gan CamiÃ±o and the CritÃ©rium du DauphinÃ©.Â 

4. Jasper Philipsen wins Tour de France Prudential Singapore CriteriumÂ 

The exhibition event of the Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium may not be an official race, but Jasper Philipsen counts it as win number 20 of the season.Â Â 

Racing 20 laps on a 3km circuit, the peloton included riders such as Tadej PogaÄar, Mark Cavendish, Chris Froome, Peter Sagan and Jonas Vingegaard. An attack from PogaÄar (of course) was reeled in 26km from the finish where Philipsen launched his powerful sprint. Cavendish finished second with PogaÄar completing the podium.Â
